Award.AwardTitle: U.S. Participation in Newton Institute Program on Stochastic Dynamical Systems in Biology: Numerical Methods and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
From January 4 through June 24, 2016, the Isaac Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences at Cambridge University in the UK will host a thematic program on Stochastic Dynamical Systems in Biology: Numerical Methods and Applications. Stochastic dynamical systems are prevalent throughout biology and medicine, and include many key processes in gene regulation, cell signaling, tissue development, and cancer proliferation. Mathematical and numerical methods are key tools in understanding both the function of these systems, and how to control and manipulate their behavior. The program will bring together a diverse set of international researchers from across the mathematical and biological sciences, each working on the design and application of such methods. The program offers a unique opportunity to exchange ideas and work collaboratively in order to tackle the many challenging open problems of the field by enabling a large number of researchers to participate for extended periods of time. To introduce graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to the field, the opening workshop will offer tutorials and plenary talks focused on providing a broad overview of current research problems. This grant provides travel funding for early career researchers and graduate students from the United States to make extended visits during the program and to participate in the program workshops.

It has become clear that to effectively understand stochasticity in biological systems, a combination of modern numerical analysis, estimation and sampling techniques, and rigorous analysis of stochastic dynamics is required. To highlight open problems and current work in these areas, the Isaac Newton Institute for the Mathematical Sciences is running a thematic program on Stochastic Dynamical Systems in Biology: Numerical Methods and Applications. The program will include an introductory, tutorial-based workshop and three research workshops, broadly focused on: multi-scale methods; well-mixed systems; and spatially distributed systems. In addition, each week of the program twenty to thirty long-term participants will be in residence, each visiting the institute for at least two weeks. The interactions between these researchers are expected to advance the field through the development of new cross-disciplinary collaborations. In the mathematical sciences these collaborations will lead to new mathematical techniques and numerical methods for studying ordinary and partial differential equations, discrete and continuous-time stochastic processes, and a variety of statistical models. To enable the broader scientific community to benefit from the program, all lectures and seminars will be available to view through the institute website (with the speaker's permission). This grant specifically supports the travel costs to visit the institute and engage in the activities of the program of several early career and trainee mathematical scientists from the United States. Further information on the program is available on the website, http://www.newton.ac.uk/event/sdb.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:

From January 4 through June 24, 2016, the Isaac Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences (INI) at Cambridge University, UK, hosted a thematic program on “Stochastic Dynamical Systems in Biology: Numerical Methods and Applications”. This project provided travel funding for 14 US participants to participate in various components of the program. The fourteen participants included eight graduate students, three postdoctoral fellows, one research associate, and two tenure-track assistant professors. The funding was intended to cover airfare, transportation to / from airports, and local housing expenses for a mix of graduate students, postdocs, and pre-tenure US researchers who did not have prior government support at the time of the program. 

 

The INI program consisted of two major components: hosting long term program participants and running four thematic workshops. Long term participants visited the INI for periods of two weeks to six months, and were provided dedicated office space and housing. To introduce participants to each other’s research, and stimulate new collaborations, program visitors spoke in weekly and biweekly seminars. The opening workshop introduced early career researchers to the field through three separate, four-part tutorial sessions, and a number of overview-style research talks. Five of the graduate student participants attended this workshop and the tutorials. The three remaining workshops were held throughout the program, and focused on current research topics related to the program theme. Most of the funded participants presented their work in some form during their visit, with graduate students giving posters and postdoctoral fellows and faculty giving workshop talks or program seminars.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Stochastic dynamical systems have been used during the last decade to model many biological processes, including gene regulation, molecular signaling, cell division and molecular transport. The development of these models has been motivated by recent advances in experimental techniques, which have revealed that many processes in cell and molecular biology are inherently stochastic. This stochasticity can provide a challenge that must be compensated for to allow proper function, such as the inherent noisiness of gene

expression. Stochasticity can also drive biological function, facilitating phenotypic diversity of cellular populations and driving evolution.

 

It has become clear that to effectively understand such systems, a combination of modern numerical analysis, estimation and sampling techniques, and rigorous analysis of stochastic dynamics is required. In addition, the large volume of experimental data being generated requires the development of new methods for its analysis, while also providing an opportunity to improve the accuracy of models and their biological predictions. The INI program aimed to advance the field by bringing together the wider scientific community working in mathematical biology, systems biology, numerical analysis, computational methods, and stochastic analysis. To achieve this goal the INI hosted 20-30 long term participants each week, each visiting the INI for a period of at least two weeks during the program. This was a unique opportunity for researchers to exchange ideas and work collaboratively in order to tackle the many challenging open problems of the field. To highlight these problems, and impact a larger set of researchers, the program also ran four five-day workshops, broadly focused on providing an introduction to the field; multiscale methods; well-mixed systems; and spatially distributed systems.

 

Broader Impacts:

By stimulating and expanding collaborations among a diverse set of international researchers from the mathematical and biological sciences, the INI program is expected to have a sustained long-term impact. The mathematical techniques and modeling approaches studied by participants include ordinary and partial differential equations, discrete and continuous-time stochastic processes, and a variety of statistical models. These are all widely applicable to problems throughout chemistry, physics, biology, engineering, and medicine. The improved algorithms and numerical methods developed by participants will also enable more in depth studies by the broader scientific community of biological processes involved in cell signaling, growth, division, tissue development, and cancer proliferation. For this reason, the tools and insights gained from the program may prove beneficial to society.

 

The program workshops introduced researchers to the broader international community of scientists interested in stochastic dynamical systems.  In particular, the opening workshop was comprised of mini-courses and overview lectures aimed at introducing graduate students and postdocs to the field, while also highlighting major open research problems. All seminars and mini-courses were streamed live on the INI webpage, and also archived and made freely available for streaming (with the speaker's permission). These online lectures and courses will provide a valuable resource for the broader mathematical and biological community.
